  <entry>
    <title>Progress in the Privacy Sandbox (January/February 2022)</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/progress-in-the-privacy-sandbox-2022-02/" />
    <updated>2022-03-04T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/progress-in-the-privacy-sandbox-2022-02/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Rowan Merewood</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><p>Welcome to the start of year edition of &quot;<strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/tags/progress-in-the-privacy-sandbox/">Progress in the Privacy
Sandbox</a></strong>&quot;, covering January and
February 2022, as we track the milestones on the path to phasing out third-party
cookies in Chrome and working towards a more private web. In each edition, we
share an overview of the updates to the <a href="https://privacysandbox.com/open-web/#the-privacy-sandbox-timeline">Privacy Sandbox
timeline</a>
along with news from across the project—and the beginning of 2022 has
plenty of updates.</p>
<h2 id="privacy-sandbox-on-android" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#privacy-sandbox-on-android" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Privacy Sandbox on Android</h2>
<p>If you have been watching the Privacy Sandbox site, you may have noticed changes
to the structure as we <a href="https://blog.google/products/android/introducing-privacy-sandbox-android/">introduced the Privacy Sandbox on
Android</a>.</p>
<p><em>&quot;We’re announcing a multi-year initiative to build the Privacy Sandbox on
Android, with the goal of introducing new, more private advertising solutions.
Specifically, these solutions will limit sharing of user data with third parties
and operate without cross-app identifiers, including advertising ID. We're also
exploring technologies that reduce the potential for covert data collection,
including safer ways for apps to integrate with advertising SDKs.&quot;</em></p>
<p>You can learn more and track progress in <a href="https://privacysandbox.com/android/#how-works-on-apps-hero">the Android section of the Privacy
Sandbox site</a>.</p>
<h2 id="feedback" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#feedback" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Feedback</h2>
<p>Getting feedback from a diverse set of stakeholders across the web ecosystem is
critical to the Privacy Sandbox initiative. We've added a <strong>dedicated <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/feedback/">feedback
section</a></strong> that provides an overview of the
existing public channels where you can follow or contribute to discussion along
with a feedback form to ensure you can always reach the Chrome team directly.</p>
<h2 id="strengthen-cross-site-privacy-boundaries" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#strengthen-cross-site-privacy-boundaries" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Strengthen cross-site privacy boundaries</h2>
<p>Third-party cookies are a key mechanism that enables cross-site tracking. Being
able to phase them out is a major milestone, but we also need to tackle other
forms of cross-site storage or communication.</p>
<h3 id="cookies" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#cookies" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Cookies</h3>
<p>As the cookie-related proposals progress, you should audit your own
<code>SameSite=None</code> or <strong>cross-site cookies</strong> and plan the action you will need to
take on your site.</p>
<h4 id="chips" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#chips" aria-hidden="true">#</a> CHIPS</h4>
<p>If you set cookies that are sent in cross-site contexts, but in 1:1
relationships—like iframe embeds, or API calls—we have added a <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/chips/">new
overview for CHIPS</a>, or Cookies Having Independent
Partitioned State. CHIPS allows you to mark cookies as &quot;<code>Partitioned</code>&quot;, which
puts them in a separate cookie jar per top-level site.</p>
<p>We've also sent the <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/_dJFNJpf91U">I2E (Intent to Experiment) for
CHIPS</a></strong>
with the plan to start the origin trial in Chrome 100 and run from March 31st,
2022 until June 30, 2022. The origin trial will be available for registration on
<a href="https://developer.chrome.com/origintrials/#/trials/active">the Chrome Origin Trials site</a>.</p>
<h4 id="additional-cookie-updates" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#additional-cookie-updates" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Additional cookie updates</h4>
<p>We're also continuing to clean up issues in general cookie implementation in
Chrome and have sent an <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/IYWGbLV-1hU">I2S (Intent to Ship) to allow cookie domain
attributes to be the empty
string</a></strong>.
Unless you are already aware that you make use of an empty domain in cookie
attributes, there is unlikely to be any developer action needed. This brings
Chrome's behavior inline with other browsers.</p>
<h3 id="federated-credentials-management" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#federated-credentials-management" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Federated Credentials Management</h3>
<p>The <a href="https://github.com/fedidcg/FedCM">Federated Credentials Management API</a>
builds on existing identity provider use cases to allow new and existing
federated identity use cases to continue without third-party cookies. We have
sent the <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/jlV_1m7uUAg">I2E for an initial FedCM origin
trials</a></strong>
starting with a limited trial from Chrome 101 on Android. This initial trial is
primarily aimed at identity providers who will eventually <a href="https://github.com/fedidcg/FedCM/blob/main/explainer/HOWTO.md">integrate
FedCM</a> into their
own libraries.</p>
<h3 id="network-state-partitioning" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#network-state-partitioning" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Network State Partitioning</h3>
<p><a href="https://github.com/MattMenke2/Explainer---Partition-Network-State">Network State
Partitioning</a>
continues the pattern implemented in <a href="https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2020/10/http-cache-partitioning">HTTP Cache
Partitioning</a>
by creating finer-grained containers for caches, which prevents cross-site
information leakage. We sent an <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/tJa6uzXu_IA">I2S to partition network
state</a></strong>
which affects websocket connections, DNS cache, and others—however after
discussion on the list we will be running additional performance experiments
before returning to this topic with a new intent.</p>
<h2 id="preventing-covert-tracking" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#preventing-covert-tracking" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Preventing covert tracking</h2>
<p>As we reduce the options for explicit cross-site tracking, we also need to
address the areas of the web platform that expose identifying information that
enables fingerprinting or covert tracking of users.</p>
<h3 id="user-agent-string-reduction-and-user-agent-client-hints" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#user-agent-string-reduction-and-user-agent-client-hints" aria-hidden="true">#</a> User-Agent string reduction and User-Agent Client Hints</h3>
<p>We are incrementally reducing the information passively available in <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/user-agent/">Chrome's
user-agent string and providing alternative User-Agent Client Hints
(UA-CH)</a> for sites that need to actively
request that information. We have sent the <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/dcTStiBZVoQ">I2S for phase 4 of the reduction
where we replace the minor
version</a></strong>
information with zeros starting in Chrome 101.</p>
<div class="compare pad-left-300" data-type="worse">
<p class="compare__label pad-bottom-200">
  Old
</p>
<p><span style="font-family: monospace">Mozilla/5.0
(Linux; Android 12; Pixel 6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko)
Chrome/101.<span style="background: #ef9a9a">0.4638.16</span> Mobile
Safari/537.36</span></p>
</div>
<div class="compare pad-left-300" data-type="better">
<p class="compare__label pad-bottom-200">
  New
</p>
<p><span style="font-family: monospace">Mozilla/5.0
(Linux; Android 12; Pixel 6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko)
Chrome/100.<span style="background: #a5d6a7">0.0.0</span> Mobile
Safari/537.36</span></p>
</div>
<p>Also starting in Chrome 101 we're launching (via an
<a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/-2OW78CB1-A">I2E</a>) the
<strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/user-agent-reduction-deprecation-trial/">User-Agent reduction deprecation
trial</a></strong>. This allows sites that
have not had time to migrate to User-Agent Client Hints to continue receiving
the full user-agent string.</p>
<p>We are continuing to improve the User-Agent Client Hints functionality. There is
a new <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/JQ68cvYuiQU">I2S for markup-based Client Hints delegation for third-party
content</a></strong>.
This allows for sites to use a <code>&lt;meta&gt;</code> tag in their HTML instead of a
<code>Permissions-Policy</code> header to send extended Client Hints on cross-origin
requests. There is also a new <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/G-ouYoNY9Hs">I2E to expand the GREASE functionality for
UA-CH</a></strong>
which is intended to encourage correct parsing of special characters, avoiding
the fragile parsing associated with the user-agent string.</p>
<h2 id="show-relevant-content-and-ads" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#show-relevant-content-and-ads" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Show relevant content and ads</h2>
<p>As we move towards phasing out third-party cookies, we are introducing APIs that
enable key use cases that sites depended on to allow them to fund their content
<strong>without</strong> continuing to enable cross-site tracking.</p>
<h3 id="topics" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#topics" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Topics</h3>
<p>The <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/topics/">Topics API</a> is a new proposal to enable
interest-based advertising without cross-site tracking. Topics was informed by
our learning and widespread community feedback from our earlier
<a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/floc/">FLoC</a> trials, and replaces our FLoC proposal. The
Topics API uses a curated taxonomy of topics to map a site to an associated
topic and provide a method to retrieve a browser's top topics.</p>
<img alt="Diagram showing the stages in the Topics API lifecycle, from a user visiting websites to an ad being displayed." decoding="async" height="275" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/80mq7dk16vVEg8BBhsVe42n6zn82/u9e1VvzblNVHCfyk1hRY.png?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<p>You can read more in the <a href="https://blog.google/products/chrome/get-know-new-topics-api-privacy-sandbox/">introductory Topics blog
post</a>
along with the full detail in the <strong><a href="https://github.com/jkarlin/topics">Topics
explainer</a></strong>. This is also linked from the
associated <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/59uTw_dxM3M">Topics
I2P</a></strong>,
announcing our intent to start coding on the feature.</p>
<h3 id="fledge" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#fledge" aria-hidden="true">#</a> FLEDGE</h3>
<p><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/fledge/">FLEDGE</a> enables remarketing and custom audience
use cases, as in advertising that can make use of sites or products previously
visited, without relying on an individual identifier.</p>
<p>FLEDGE is <strong><a href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/Proposed_First_FLEDGE_OT_Details.md">preparing for an initial origin
trial</a></strong>
with details available for discussion in the repository. Alongside this we have
also published a <strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/fledge-api/">detailed developer guide</a></strong>.</p>
<h2 id="measure-digital-ads" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#measure-digital-ads" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Measure digital ads</h2>
<p>As the companion to displaying ads without cross-site tracking, we need
privacy-preserving mechanisms to enable measuring the effectiveness of those
ads.</p>
<h3 id="attribution-reporting-api" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#attribution-reporting-api" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Attribution Reporting API</h3>
<p>The <strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting/">Attribution Reporting
API</a></strong> enables functionality to
measure events on one site, like clicking or viewing an ad, that lead to a
conversion on another site—without enabling cross-site tracking.</p>
<p>A number of new changes landed in the Attribution Reporting API proposal. We
have made a full list available in the <strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting-changes-january-2022/">Attribution Reporting API January 2022
update</a></strong>.
This includes an <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting/summary-reports/"><strong>overview of summary
reports</strong></a>
(previously referred to as aggregate reports). Summary reports provide an
aggregated view of detailed conversion data, while retaining critical
information for reporting, without the ability to identify individual users
within that data. <strong>Event-level reporting</strong> added <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting-changes-january-2022/#new-features">new
features</a>
for third-party reporting, view-through measurement, filtering reports, and
debugging functionality.</p>
<h2 id="article-feedback" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#article-feedback" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Article feedback</h2>
<p>As we continue to publish these updates and progress through the Privacy Sandbox
as a whole, we want to make sure that you as a developer are getting the
information and support that you need. Let us know on <a href="https://twitter.com/ChromiumDev">@ChromiumDev
Twitter</a> if there's anything that we could
improve in this series. We'll use your input to continue improving the format.</p>
</content>
  </entry>
  
  
  <entry>
    <title>Deprecations and removals in Chrome 100</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/deps-rems-100/" />
    <updated>2022-03-04T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/deps-rems-100/</id>
    
    <author>
      <name>Chrome Developers</name>
    </author>
    
    <content type="html"><div class="aside aside--note">
<p>Visit ChromeStatus.com for lists of <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#browsers.chrome.status%3A%22Deprecated%22">current deprecations</a> and <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#browsers.chrome.status:%22Removed%22">previous removals</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Chrome 100 beta was released on March 3, 2022 and is expected to become the
stable version in late March, 2022.</p>
<h2 id="last-version-for-unreduced-user-agent-string" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#last-version-for-unreduced-user-agent-string" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Last Version for Unreduced User-Agent String</h2>
<p>Chromium 100 will be the last version to support an unreduced User-Agent string by default (as well as the related <code>navigator.userAgent</code>, <code>navigator.appVersion</code>, and <code>navigator.platform</code> DOM APIs). The origin trial that <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/origintrials/#/view_trial/-7123568710593282047">allowed sites to test the fully reduced User-Agent</a> will end on April 19, 2022. After that date, the User-Agent String will be gradually reduced. To review the whole schedule, see <a href="https://blog.chromium.org/2021/09/user-agent-reduction-origin-trial-and-dates.html">Chromium Blog: User-Agent Reduction Origin Trial and Dates</a>. Sites that need more time to test or <a href="https://web.dev/migrate-to-ua-ch/">migrate to User-Agent Client Hints</a> can enroll in the deprecation origin trial <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/origintrials/#/view_trial/2608710084154359809">scheduled from Chrome 100 to 113</a>, inclusive. In contrast to the first origin trial, which previews the fully reduced User-Agent string, the deprecation trial maintains the legacy User-Agent. The deprecation trial is expected to end in late May of 2023.</p>
<p>This is part of a strategy to replace use of the User-Agent string with the
new User-Agent Client Hints API. To learn about User-Agent Client Hints, see <a href="https://web.dev/migrate-to-ua-ch/">Migrate to User-Agent Client Hints</a> and <a href="https://web.dev/user-agent-client-hints/">Improving user privacy and developer experience with User-Agent Client Hints</a>.</p>
<h2 id="deprecation-policy" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#deprecation-policy" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Deprecation policy</h2>
<p>To keep the platform healthy, we sometimes remove APIs from the Web Platform
which have run their course. There can be many reasons why we would remove an
API, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>They are superseded by newer APIs.</li>
<li>They are updated to reflect changes to specifications to bring alignment and
consistency with other browsers.</li>
<li>They are early experiments that never came to fruition in other browsers and
thus can increase the burden of support for web developers.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some of these changes will have an effect on a very small number of sites. To
mitigate issues ahead of time, we try to give developers advanced notice so they
can make the required changes to keep their sites running.</p>
<p>Chrome currently has a <a href="http://www.chromium.org/blink#TOC-Launch-Process:-Deprecation">process for deprecations and removals of
API's</a>,
essentially:</p>
<ul>
<li>Announce on the
<a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!forum/blink-dev">blink-dev</a>
mailing list.</li>
<li>Set warnings and give time scales in the Chrome DevTools Console when usage
is detected on the page.</li>
<li>Wait, monitor, and then remove the feature as usage drops.</li>
</ul>
<p>You can find a list of all deprecated features on chromestatus.com using the
<a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#deprecated">deprecated filter</a> and
removed features by applying the <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#removed">removed
filter</a>. We will also try to
summarize some of the changes, reasoning, and migration paths in these posts.</p>
</content>
  </entry>
  
  
  <entry>
    <title>It's always been you, Canvas2D</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/canvas2d/" />
    <updated>2022-03-03T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/canvas2d/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Aaron Krajeski</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><p>In a world of shaders, meshes, and filters, Canvas2D might not get you excited.
But it should! 30-40% of web pages have a <code>&lt;canvas&gt;</code> element and 98% of all canvases use a Canvas2D rendering context.
There are Canvas2Ds in cars, on fridges, <a href="https://lithiosapps.com/a-look-under-the-hood-of-spacexs-dragon-capsule/">and in space</a> (really).</p>
<p>Admittedly, the API is a bit behind the times when it comes to state-of-the-art 2D drawing.
Fortunately we've been hard at work implementing new features in Canvas2D to catch up to CSS, streamline ergonomics and improve performance.</p>
<h2 id="part-1-catching-up-with-css" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#part-1-catching-up-with-css" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Part 1: catching up with CSS</h2>
<p>CSS has a few drawing commands that are sorely missing from Canvas2D. With the new API we've added a handful of the most requested features:</p>
<h3 id="round-rect" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#round-rect" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Round rect</h3>
<p>Rounded rectangles: the cornerstone of the internet, of computing, nigh, of civilization.</p>
<p>In all seriousness, rounded rectangles are extremely useful: as buttons, chat bubbles, thumbnails, speech bubbles, you name it. It's always been possible to make a rounded rectangle in Canvas2D, it's just been a bit messy:</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">  <span class="token keyword">const</span> canvas <span class="token operator">=</span> document<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">getElementById</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">"canvas"</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">const</span> ctx <span class="token operator">=</span> canvas<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">getContext</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">"2d"</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span>fillStyle <span class="token operator">=</span> “magenta”<span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><br>  <span class="token keyword">const</span> top <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">const</span> left <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">const</span> width <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">200</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">const</span> height <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">100</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">const</span> radius <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">20</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">beginPath</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">moveTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>left <span class="token operator">+</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">lineTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>left <span class="token operator">+</span> width <span class="token operator">-</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">arcTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>left <span class="token operator">+</span> width<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top<span class="token punctuation">,</span> left <span class="token operator">+</span> width<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top <span class="token operator">+</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">,</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>  <br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">lineTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>left <span class="token operator">+</span> width<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top <span class="token operator">+</span> height <span class="token operator">-</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">arcTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><br>left <span class="token operator">+</span> width<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top <span class="token operator">+</span> height<span class="token punctuation">,</span> left <span class="token operator">+</span> width <span class="token operator">-</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <br>top <span class="token operator">+</span> height<span class="token punctuation">,</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">lineTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>left <span class="token operator">+</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top <span class="token operator">+</span> height<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">arcTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>left<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top <span class="token operator">+</span> height<span class="token punctuation">,</span> left<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top <span class="token operator">+</span> height <span class="token operator">-</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">,</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">)</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">lineTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>left<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top <span class="token operator">+</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">arcTo</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>left<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top<span class="token punctuation">,</span> left <span class="token operator">+</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">,</span> top<span class="token punctuation">,</span> radius<span class="token punctuation">)</span><br>  ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">stroke</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></code></pre>
<p>All this was necessary for a modest, simple rounded rectangle:</p>
<img alt="A rounded rectangle." decoding="async" height="150" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 300px) 300px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/kheDArv5csY6rvQUJDbWRscckLr1/J9JnDFq28BhDGsMyw2zY.png?auto=format&w=600 600w" width="300">
<p>With the new API there's a <code>roundRect()</code> method.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">	ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">roundRect</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>upper<span class="token punctuation">,</span> left<span class="token punctuation">,</span> width<span class="token punctuation">,</span> height<span class="token punctuation">,</span> borderRadius<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><br>	So the above can be wholly replaced by<span class="token operator">:</span><br><br>	ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">roundRect</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">200</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">100</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">20</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></code></pre>
<p><code>ctx.roundRect()</code> also takes in an array for the <code>borderRadius</code> argument of up to four numbers. These radii control the four corners of the rounded rectangle the same way <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/border-radius">as for CSS</a>. For example:</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">	ctx<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">roundRect</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">200</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">100</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">15</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">50</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">30</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre>
<p><a href="https://pickle-gorgeous-treatment.glitch.me/">Check out the demo to play around</a>!</p>
<h3 id="conic-gradient" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#conic-gradient" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Conic Gradient</h3>

class="token function">createLinearGradient</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token gradient<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">addColorStop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token
