  <entry>
    <title>Deprecations and removals in Chrome 99</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/deps-rems-99/" />
    <updated>2022-02-03T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/deps-rems-99/</id>
    
    <author>
      <name>Chrome Developers</name>
    </author>
    
    <content type="html"><div class="aside aside--note">
<p>Visit ChromeStatus.com for lists of <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#browsers.chrome.status%3A%22Deprecated%22">current deprecations</a> and <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#browsers.chrome.status:%22Removed%22">previous removals</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Chrome 99 beta was released on February 3, 2022 and is expected to become the
stable version in early March, 2022.</p>
<h2 id="remove-battery-status-api-on-insecure-origins" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#remove-battery-status-api-on-insecure-origins" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Remove Battery Status API on insecure origins</h2>
<p><a href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/4878376799043584">Battery Status API is no longer supported on insecure origins</a>,
such as HTTP pages or HTTPS iframes embedded in HTTP pages. The Battery Status
API allows web developers to access, among other things, a system's battery
charging level and whether it is being charged. It is a powerful feature that
has been around for over a decade and, as such, was originally designed with
different security constraints.</p>
<h2 id="remove-font-family-webkit-standard" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#remove-font-family-webkit-standard" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Remove font-family -webkit-standard</h2>
<p>This version of Chrome
<a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5639265565278208">removes support for the <code>font-family</code> value <code>&quot;-webkit-standard&quot;</code></a>.
This value is merely an alias for the proprietary keyword <code>&quot;-webkit-body&quot;</code> and
is only exposed because it's inherited from WebKit. Removing this improves
alignment with the CSS specifications and with Firefox.</p>
<h2 id="remove-gamepadlist" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#remove-gamepadlist" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Remove GamepadList</h2>
<p>The
<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Navigator/getGamepads"><code>navigator.getGamepads()</code></a>
method now returns an array of
<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Gamepad"><code>Gamepad</code></a> objects
<a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5693119438782464">instead of a GamepadList</a>.
<code>GamepadList</code> is no longer supported in Chrome. This brings Chrome in line with
specification and with Gecko and Webkit. For information on Gamepads generally, see <a href="https://web.dev/gamepad/">Play
the Chrome dino game with your gamepad</a>.</p>
<h2 id="update-webcodecs-to-match-the-specification" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#update-webcodecs-to-match-the-specification" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Update WebCodecs to match the specification</h2>
<p>Chrome has <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5667793157488640">removed two
items</a> because of
recent changes in the WebCodecs specification.</p>
<p>The <code>EncodedVideoChunkOutputCallback()</code> method takes an
<code>EncodedVideoChunkMetadata</code> dictionary. Previously a member called
<code>temporalLayerId</code> was located at <code>EncodedVideoChunkMetadata.temporalLayerId</code>. In
line with the specification, it is now located at
<code>EncodedVideoChunkMetadata.SvcOutputMetadata.temporalLayerId</code>.</p>
<p>The specification requires that the <code>VideoFrame()</code> constructor include a timestamp
argument (<code>VideoFrameInit.timestamp</code>) for <code>CanvasImageSource</code> types that don't
implicitly have a timestamp (for example, <code>HTMLCanvasElement</code>). Failing to include the
timestamp should result in a <code>TypeError</code>, but Chrome previously defaulted the
timestamp to zero. This seems helpful, but is problematic if you then send the
<code>VideoFrame</code> to a <code>VideoEncoder</code>, where timestamps are used to guide bitrate
control.</p>
<h2 id="deprecation-policy" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#deprecation-policy" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Deprecation policy</h2>
<p>To keep the platform healthy, we sometimes remove APIs from the Web Platform
which have run their course. There can be many reasons why we would remove an
API, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>They are superseded by newer APIs.</li>
<li>They are updated to reflect changes to specifications to bring alignment and
consistency with other browsers.</li>
<li>They are early experiments that never came to fruition in other browsers and
thus can increase the burden of support for web developers.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some of these changes will have an effect on a very small number of sites. To
mitigate issues ahead of time, we try to give developers advanced notice so they
can make the required changes to keep their sites running.</p>
<p>Chrome currently has a <a href="http://www.chromium.org/blink#TOC-Launch-Process:-Deprecation">process for deprecations and removals of
API's</a>,
essentially:</p>
<ul>
<li>Announce on the
<a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!forum/blink-dev">blink-dev</a>
mailing list.</li>
<li>Set warnings and give time scales in the Chrome DevTools Console when usage
is detected on the page.</li>
<li>Wait, monitor, and then remove the feature as usage drops.</li>
</ul>
<p>You can find a list of all deprecated features on chromestatus.com using the
<a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#deprecated">deprecated filter</a> and
removed features by applying the <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#removed">removed
filter</a>. We will also try to
summarize some of the changes, reasoning, and migration paths in these posts.</p>
</content>
  </entry>
  
  
  <entry>
    <title>Permissions request chip</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/permissions-chip/" />
    <updated>2022-02-01T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/permissions-chip/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Thomas Steiner</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><h2 id="the-permissions-ux-until-now" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#the-permissions-ux-until-now" aria-hidden="true">#</a> The permissions UX until now</h2>
<p>When a user visits a site that requests a permission, a bubble pops up to prompt the user to make a
decision. For example, below you can see the geolocation permission prompt as implemented in Chrome
up to version 96. (You can try this and other permissions on our demo site
<a href="https://permission.site/">permission.site</a>.)</p>
<img alt="Chrome geolocation permission prompt" decoding="async" height="432" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 690px) 690px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/dVZNzWjq3wBsRY4E7ShO.png?auto=format&w=1380 1380w" width="690">
<h3 id="most-permission-prompts-are-ignored-or-dismissed" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#most-permission-prompts-are-ignored-or-dismissed" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Most permission prompts are ignored or dismissed</h3>
<p>Chrome's telemetry data proves that a lot of permission prompts are ignored. You can explore the
<a href="https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2020/02/notification-permission-data-in-crux">notification permission data</a>
in the Chrome UX report yourself. For now, consider the table below that shows
how Windows users reacted to the notification prompt on sites in an accumulated way, while noting
that geolocation prompts saw a similar dismiss or ignore behavior.</p>
<div class="table-wrapper scrollbar">
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Action</th>
<th>Percent of notification prompts</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Allow</td>
<td>6.69%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Block</td>
<td>9.20%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Dismiss</td>
<td>35.76%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Ignore</td>
<td>47.19%</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
<p>Given an ignore/dismiss rate of approximately 85%, and especially given how much the prompt stands out and
insists on users making a decision immediately, there is a conflict between the level of urgency
assumed by the browser versus the user's preference for waiting to make a decision. This creates the
perception that it's &quot;annoying&quot; for a site to ask for a permission because it will be lost in the potential extra
things users need to react to like cookie consent banners, newsletter signups, etc.</p>
<h2 id="new-design" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#new-design" aria-hidden="true">#</a> New design</h2>
<p>From Chrome 98 on, we therefore introduced an animated chip UI which appears next to the lock
whenever a permission is requested. This consists of an icon and label describing the permission being
requested. Our aim was to improve the experience of web browsing while avoiding permission requests
that are generally unnecessary for the vast majority of users and frequently ignored or dismissed.</p>
<p><video autoplay="" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">      <source src="https://storage.googleapis.com/web-dev-uploads/video/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/4rH9koYThnPvEgLu4mF6.mp4" type="video/mp4">    </video></p>
<p>The existing prompt bubble will be shown when the request chip is clicked (if not already shown) and
the request UI is automatically augmented with the request bubble based on the heuristics listed
below:</p>
<ul>
<li>The permission was triggered through a user gesture when interacting with the site itself rather
than automatically triggered by the site.</li>
<li>The permission is deemed essential and generally non-spammy. Currently this includes camera,
microphone, and camera paired with microphone.</li>
</ul>
<img alt="Flow diagram going from padlock to the geolocation prompt, which, if dismissed, results in the &#x27;geolocation blocked&#x27; icon, which, after a four second delay, is finally replaced with the padlock again." decoding="async" height="303" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/LoPc4O4atyPkXdSKh7gh.png?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<h3 id="forcing-the-new-design" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#forcing-the-new-design" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Forcing the new design</h3>
<p>Since this is a staged rollout, you can force the new design by toggling the following flags:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>chrome://flags/#permission-chip</code></li>
<li><code>chrome://flags/#permission-chip-gesture</code></li>
<li><code>chrome://flags/#permission-chip-request-type</code></li>
</ul>
<h3 id="flow-of-the-new-design" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#flow-of-the-new-design" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Flow of the new design</h3>
<h4 id="without-user-gesture" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#without-user-gesture" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Without user gesture</h4>
<p>For non-essential permissions not triggered by a gesture, the prompt no longer intrudes on the site
contents, and does not insist on an immediate decision. The user can ignore the request chip until
they have enough information to make a decision.</p>
<h4 id="without-interaction" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#without-interaction" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Without interaction</h4>
<p>With no interaction, and after a short delay, the request chip will automatically collapse to just a
blocked icon (to indicate the permission being temporarily blocked), before being dismissed
entirely. The aim is to get out of the way of users who choose not to make a decision letting them do so
without any interaction.</p>
<img alt="Flow diagram going from padlock to the unobtrusive geolocation chip, which, after a twelve second delay results in the &#x27;geolocation blocked&#x27; icon, which, after a four second delay, is finally replaced with the padlock again." decoding="async" height="140" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/8WbTDNrhLsU0El80frMBGE4eMCD3/73sL3v6PG3VSFjtrHZr6.png?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<h3 id="expected-short-term-impact" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#expected-short-term-impact" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Expected short-term impact</h3>
<p>In the short term, and until users get used to the new UI, it is likely that site owners will observe
lower grant rates for sites, especially for those that auto-request permissions without priming or
demanding a user gesture (which is considered a <a href="https://web.dev/notification-on-start/">bad practice</a> anyway). This
acknowledged downside is vastly outweighed by the less interruptive experience.</p>
<h3 id="best-practices" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#best-practices" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Best practices</h3>
<p>It is up to the site to ensure it provides the necessary context and only requests permissions at
the appropriate and expected moment. Permissions that have been temporarily blocked—through a user
ignoring the request or dismissing the prompt—can request the permission again within the same
session. Only do this if the permission is essential for the site or feature to work, otherwise it
runs the risk of annoying users and getting auto blocked. In those cases we show the
<a href="https://blog.chromium.org/2020/01/introducing-quieter-permission-ui-for.html">quiet messaging</a> that
was introduced in Chrome 80. For more general guidance, see
<a href="https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/push-notifications/permission-ux">Permission UX</a>.</p>
<h2 id="outlook-and-conclusions" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#outlook-and-conclusions" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Outlook and conclusions</h2>
<p>There are plans for further UI and UX improvements. The Chrome team is already working on
them and investigating potentially more aggressive auto-blocking of permissions
based on prior behavior. You will learn about the news here once these plans mature.</p>
<p>Concluding, the new UI reduces the perceived insistence on a decision and improves the browsing
experience. Since most permission prompts are blocked or ignored, the met objective was to improve the
general experience of browsing, while not breaking user flows when showing a permission prompt,
especially in situations where permissions are required to complete a use case.</p>
<h2 id="acknowledgements" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#acknowledgements" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Acknowledgements</h2>
<p>Hero image by <a href="https://unsplash.com/@sigmund">Sigmund</a> on
<a href="https://unsplash.com/photos/UmaojK7erQo">Unsplash</a>. This article was reviewed by
<a href="https://github.com/jpmedley">Joe Medley</a>.</p>
</content>
  </entry>
  
  
  <entry>
    <title>New in Chrome 98</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/new-in-chrome-98/" />
    <updated>2022-02-01T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/new-in-chrome-98/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Pete LePage</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><div class="youtube">
  <iframe class="youtube__embed" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/VLjOIiOt7Do" title="youtube embed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen="" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<p>Here's what you need to know:</p>
<ul>
<li>If you’ve tried the Auto Dark Theme origin trial, there’s a new way to
<a href="#autodark-opt-out">opt out at a per element level</a>.</li>
<li>There’s now support for <a href="#colrv1">COLRv1</a>, an evolution of the COLRv0 font
format.</li>
<li>And there's plenty <a href="#more">more</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>I'm <a href="https://petelepage.com/">Pete LePage</a>. Let's dive in and
see what's new for developers in Chrome 98.</p>
<h2 id="autodark-opt-out" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#autodark-opt-out" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Opting out of auto-dark themes on Android</h2>
<p>In Chrome 96, we started an origin trial for
<a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/auto-dark-theme/">Auto Dark Themes on Android</a>.</p>
<p>With this feature, if your site is light themed and the user’s OS is in dark
mode, the browser applies an automatically generated dark theme to your site.</p>
<p>If you've signed up for the origin trial, and you want to opt out of the
automatically generated dark theme for a specific page, you can use a meta tag.</p>
<pre class="language-html"><code class="language-html"><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>meta</span> <span class="token attr-name">name</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>color-scheme<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span> <span class="token attr-name">content</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>only light<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span></code></pre>
<p>Or you can opt-out by setting <code>color-scheme: only light</code> on the <code>:root</code>
element.</p>
<pre class="language-css"><code class="language-css"><span class="token selector">:root</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token property">color-scheme</span><span class="token punctuation">:</span> only light<span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre>
<p>But the main advantage of this method, is that you can opt out on a
per-element basis by applying a specific style to that element.</p>
<pre class="language-css"><code class="language-css"><span class="token selector">.only-light,<br>#my-element</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token property">color-scheme</span><span class="token punctuation">:</span> only light<span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre>
<p>Check out the <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/auto-dark-theme/#per-element-opt-out">How to opt-out of Auto Dark Theme</a> section
in <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/auto-dark-theme/">Auto Dark Themes on Android</a> for complete details.</p>
<h2 id="colrv1" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#colrv1" aria-hidden="true">#</a> COLRv1 font support</h2>
<p>In Chrome 98, there’s now <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/colrv1-fonts/">support for COLRv1</a>, an evolution of
the COLRv0 font format. It adds gradients, compositing and blending, and
improved shape reuse for crisp and compact font files that compress well.</p>
<p>A color font makes visual highlights, headlines, and banners really pop out.</p>
<img alt="Headline using COLRv1 fonts" decoding="async" height="661" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/qTY5GIw3dMKnQARZZeGx.png?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<p>One of my favorite use cases for COLRv1 means consistent emojis across all
platforms. You don't need to replace emojis with image files, because font
files become smaller, and easier to include on your page.</p>
<img alt="Font file using consistent emoji" decoding="async" height="612" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 640px) 640px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/1UL0zMDpXPEQnKNlXk3U.png?auto=format&w=1280 1280w" width="640">
<p>We’re working on ways to improve feature detection, since it’s not as easy as
it should be yet. But this is something to keep an eye on.</p>
<p>Check out <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/colrv1-fonts/">COLRv1 Color Gradient Vector Fonts in Chrome 98</a> for
more details and how you can create your own fonts.</p>
<h2 id="chrome-100" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#chrome-100" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Emulate Chrome 100 in the UA string</h2>
<p>In just a few months, we'll hit Chrome 100, a <strong>three</strong> digit version number.
Any code that checks version numbers, or parses the UA string, should be
checked to make sure it handles three digits.</p>
<p>There's a flag called <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/force-major-version-to-100/"><code>#force-major-version-to-100</code></a> that
will change the current version number to 100, so you can make sure
everything works as expected.</p>
<img alt="Chrome flags page highlighting the new #force-major-version-to-100 option" decoding="async" height="533" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/4drS8JxKXgtzSAxyM6WF.png?auto=format" https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/4drS8JxKXgtzSAxyM6WF.png?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/4drS8JxKXgtzSAxyM6WF.png?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<h2 id="more" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#more" aria-hidden="true">#</a> And more!</h2>
<p>Of course there's plenty more.</p>
<p><a href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5737414355058688">CORS preflight requests</a> are now sent ahead of private
network requests for subresources, asking for explicit permission from the
target server.</p>
<p>There’s a new origin trial for <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/origintrials/#/view_trial/2257429313219461121">Region Capture</a>, an API for
cropping a self-capture video track. Ideal for screen sharing in video
conferencing apps so you don’t create a hall of mirror effect!</p>
<p>Window overlay controls had been planned for Chrome 98, but due to issues found
at the last minute, did not make it in. We are still working on it, and
expect to see it land in the next few releases.</p>
<h2 id="further-reading" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#further-reading" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Further reading</h2>
<p>This covers only some of the key highlights. Check the links below for
additional changes in Chrome 98.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-98/">What's new in Chrome DevTools (98)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/deps-rems-98/">Chrome 98 deprecations and removals</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#milestone%3D98">ChromeStatus.com updates for Chrome 98</a></li>
<li><a href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/97.0.4692.71..98.0.4758.88">Chromium source repository change list</a></li>
<li><a href="https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/schedule">Chrome release calendar</a></li>
</ul>
<h2 id="subscribe" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#subscribe" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Subscribe</h2>
<p>To stay up to date, <a href="https://goo.gl/6FP1a5">subscribe</a>
to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/user/ChromeDevelopers/">Chrome Developers YouTube channel</a>,
and you'll get an email notification whenever we launch a new video.</p>
<p>I'm Pete LePage, and as soon as Chrome 99 is released, I'll be right here to
tell you what's new in Chrome!</p>
